column8: The students enjoyed unloading and organizing the items on shelves that prior to our visit were pretty bare. They got to see an adult ESL class and help out in the childcare room.
column9: Seeing the shelves restocked with items that would lift the financial burden for a refugee family helped me see the impact of direct giving.
column10: As one student said on our bus ride back to school, "You don't have to cross the ocean to help, just cross the street."
column13: I will remember seeing my students playing with young children who don't speak English. They were warm, creative, and open-minded to helping out where help was needed in the moment.
column17: The students want to take action with Project Worthmore in conjunction with next year's WAC theme of "Smart World."
column20: Allowing people to sign up for non-monetary donations would be a nice addition. They signed up as "volunteers," which also worked but was confusing to a couple users.
column21: I hope more WAC teams can use The Philanthropy Project to plan, manage, and reflect on the action component of their project.
